title: Phase II study of nivolumab (anti-PD1). tadalafil. and oral vancomycin in patients with refractory primary hepatocellular carcinoma or liver dominant metastatic cancer from …
author: M Cecilia Monge B and Changqing Xie and Donna Mabry-Hrones and Bradford J Wood and Seth M Steinberg and David E Kleiner and Tim F Greten
abstract: TPS4656Background: Treatment options for advanced hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) and liver dominant metastatic disease from colorectal or pancreatic cancers are limited with poor overall survival. Tadalafil has shown to increase anti-tumor immunity by decreasing myeloid derived suppressor cells (MDSC) and impair tumor growth in preclinical HCC models. Oral vancomycin affects bile acid metabolizing gut commensal bacteria leading to increased CXCL16 expression in the liver resulting in NKT mediated liver-selective anti-tumor effects. This study combines immune checkpoint inhibition (ICI) treatment with nivolumab in combination with tadalafil and oral vancomycin. We aim to evaluate the synergy of the antitumor effect induced by the change in gut microbiome with oral vancomycin and the immunomodulatory effect of PDE5 inhibition combined with ICI with nivolumab in advanced liver cancer or liver …

title: 742 ACTIVE HBV TRANSCRIPTION AND TRANSLATION PERSIST DESPITE SUPPRESSION OF VIRAL REPLICATION IN HIV/HBV CO-INFECTED PATIENTS RECEIVING DUALLY ACTIVE ANTIRETROVIRAL THERAPY
author: Mauricio Lisker-Melman and Abdus S Wahed and Raymond T Chung and Marc G Ghany and David Kleiner and Atul K Bhan and Mandana Khalili and Mamta K Jain and Mark S Sulkowski and David Wong and Gavin A Cloherty and Richard K Sterling
abstract: Background: Chronic hepatitis B (CHB) and nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) are significant public health problems. Patients with CHB and NAFLD were reported to have increased risk of advanced hepatic fibrosis. In North America. majority of the CHB patients are Asians and about 30% have NAFLD. Lipoprotein insulin resistance (LP-IR) score by NMR is accurate in identifying IR. precursor of NAFLD. in the general population but has not been evaluated in patients with underlying liver disease. In addition. decreased small VLDL and increased large VLDL concentrations have been associated with hepatic steatosis and advanced liver fibrosis. Aim: To assess the usefulness of LP-IR score and VLDL profiles in identifying CHB patients with metabolic syndrome and diabetes mellitus who are at risk for developing NAFLD. Methods: We systematically selected patients with CHB alone (HBV). HBV with …

title: 382 ASSOCIATION BETWEEN IMMUNOHISTOCHEMICAL STAINING FOR HBV ANTIGENS IN LIVER BIOPSIES AND CIRCULATING HBV DNA AND OTHER CHARACTERISTICS OF HBV VIRAL INFECTION
author: David Kleiner and Abdus Wahed and Atul K Bhan and Michael A Nalesnik and Eun-Young Choi and Rageshree Ramachandran and Kelsey Leonard and Adrian Di Bisceglie and Marc G Ghany and Raymond T Chung and Mauricio Lisker-Melman
abstract: Background: Sarcopenia is the loss of muscle mass and function seen in cirrhosis (Cir). There is emerging evidence for the role of hepatic amino acid metabolism in sarcopenia. A possible role of the gut microbiome in the development of sarcopenia via amino acid metabolism has not been fully explored in humans with Cir. Aim: To explore the mechanism of sarcopenia in Cir by interrogating the portal vein and gut microbiome. Methods: HCV patients had a liver biopsy with portal vein cannulation before (n= 27) and 1 year after DAA therapy (23). Ishak fibrosis (IF) was used to score fibrosis. Metabolomics was performed on portal serum and clustered using similarity network fusion analysis. RNA-seq assessed fecal metatranscriptome and liver transcriptome. Cir and non-cirrhotics (NC) were compared using DeSeq2 and GSEA (FDR p< 0.05). Diet was quantified using validated questionnaires. Muscle volume (MV …

title: Molecular landscape of tumor ecosystem and its evolution in liver cancer
author: L Ma and L Wang and M Forgues and S Franck and CW Chang and SP Martin and DE Kleiner and BJ Wood and TF Greten and XW Wang
journal: Primary Liver Cancer–Emerging Concepts and Novel Treatments
abstract: Cancer is the result of an evolutionary process leading to vast intratumor and intertumoral molecular heterogeneity and a complex mutational landscape. Tumor cellular diversity is key factor for therapeutic failures and cancer-related mortality. This is especially relevant to hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) and intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma (iCCA). the two major histological types of liver cancer. where various etiological factors may elicit different molecular mechanisms to initiate carcinogenesis. which lead to different molecularly distinct subtypes and complex tumor cell communities. Such heterogeneity poses a major challenge to define drivers responsible for early stage hepatocarcinogenesis and develop diagnostic tools and treatment modalities for HCC and iCCA. Characterization of tumor cell communities at the singlecell level may help shed light on the panorama of tumor biodiversity. We determined single-cell transcriptome and cellular landscape of HCC and iCCA from patients who were enrolled for immune checkpoint inhibition trials at the NIH Clinical Center. We found varying degrees of transcriptomic heterogeneity in malignant cells within and between tumors as well as diverse landscapes of tumor microenvironment (TME). We also found evidence of heterogeneity in cellular stemness. We developed methods to measure intratumoral diversity and tumor cell clonality. Strikingly. intratumoral diversity of malignant cells was associated with patient outcomes where tumors with higher diversity were associated with worse prognosis and TME reprogramming. The link between intratumor heterogeneity and patient prognosis was also …

Liu's method utilizes second-harmonic generation microscopy images to visualize and quantify fibrosis-related parameters as well as two-photon excitation fluorescence microscopy images to visualize and quantify inflammation-. ballooning-. and steatosis-related parameters. We commend the authors for their important work.

title: A phase I/II study of Pexa-Vec oncolytic virus in combination with immune checkpoint inhibition in refractory colorectal cancer.
author: M Cecilia Monge B and Changqing Xie and Seth M Steinberg and Suzanne Fioraventi and Melissa Walker and Donna Mabry-Hrones and Bradford J Wood and David E Kleiner and Tim F Greten
abstract: 117Background: The benefit of immune checkpoint inhibition is limited to the small percentage of advanced colorectal cancer (CRC) patients whose tumors present mismatch repair (MMR) gene abnormalities; immunotherapy has not shown benefit in patients with MMR proficient CRC. Oncolytic immunotherapy represents a unique therapeutic platform. This phase I trial tests the safety of the combination of pexastimogene devacirepvec (Pexa-Vec) plus durvalumab (durva) in patients with locally advanced or metastatic CRC. Methods: Eligible patients with advanced proficient mixed match repair (pMMR) CRC received intravenous infusion of Pexa-Vec at dose level 3 x 108 plaque forming units (pfu) (DL1) or at 109 pfu (DL2) every 2 weeks for 4 doses and durva 1500 mg every 28 days. Response was assessed with CT every 8 weeks. Adverse events were recorded and managed. The primary endpoint included …

title: Analysis of TP53 aflatoxin signature mutation in hepatocellular carcinomas from Guatemala: A cross-sectional study
author: Christian S Alvarez and Jeremy Ortiz and Giovanna Bendfeldt-Avila and Yi Xie and Mingyi Wang and Dongjing Wu and Herbert Higson and Elisa Lee and Kedest Teshome and Joaquin Barnoya and David E Kleiner and John D Groopman and Roberto Orozco and Katherine A McGlynn and Eduardo Gharzouzi and Michael Dean
abstract: Background and aims: Guatemala has the highest incidence of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in the Western hemisphere. The major risk factors in Guatemala are not well characterized. but the prevalence of hepatitis B virus (HBV) and hepatitis C virus (HCV) appears to be low. while the prevalence of aflatoxin (AFB1) exposure appears to be high. To examine whether AFB1 may contribute to the elevated incidence of HCC in Guatemala. this study examined the frequency of the AFB1-signature mutation in the TP53 gene (R249S) as well as other somatic mutations. In addition. we assessed whether the frequency of the TP53 mutation differed by sex. Methods: Formalin-fixed. paraffin-embedded (FFPE) HCC tissues were obtained from three hospitals in Guatemala City between 2016 and 2017. In addition. tumor tissues preserved in RNAlater were also obtained. Sociodemographic and clinical information including HBV and HCV status were collected. Targeted sequencing of TP53 was performed in the FFPE samples. and a panel of 253 cancer-related genes was sequenced in the RNAlater samples.Results: Ninety-one FFPE tissues were examined. from 52 men and 39 women. Median (IQR) age at diagnosis was 62 (51-70). Among those with known HBV and HCV status. two were HBV+ and three were HCV+. Overall. 47% of the HCCs had a TP53 mutation. The AFB1-signature R249S mutation was present in 24%. No overlap between the R249S mutation and HBV+ was observed in this cohort. Among 18 RNAlater samples examined. 44% had any TP53 mutation and 33% had the R249S mutation. Other somatic mutations were identified in …

title: The first malignant primary hepatic glomus tumor: A case report
author: John G Aversa and Cara Monroe and Amelia Levi and Antonios Papanicolau-Sengos and David E Kleiner and Jonathan M Hernandez
journal: International Journal of Surgery Case Reports
abstract: Glomus tumors (GTs) are rare neoplasms that originate from the modified smooth muscle cells of glomus bodies and occasionally arise from visceral primary sites. All previously reported primary hepatic GTs were benign. Here we report the first malignant primary hepatic GT.Our patient is a 60-year-old male who presented with weight loss. early satiety. night sweats. and abdominal distention. Imaging demonstrated a large mass abutting the stomach. duodenum. and head of the pancreas. exerting mass effect on the portal vein and inferior vena cava. Biopsy results were deemed nondiagnostic after extensive review at multiple academic institutions. We performed a caudate lobe resection. antrectomy. and Bilroth II gastrojejunostomy that required skeletonization of much of the periportal vascular anatomy and the repair of multiple venotomies due to the tumor’s adherence to the …

title: Letter to the Editor: Noninvasive Markers of Advanced Liver Fibrosis in HBV/HIV Coinfected Patients Reply

title: Analysis of TP53 gene mutations demonstrates that aflatoxin is a risk factor for hepatocellular carcinoma in Guatemala
author: Christian Alvarez Privado and Jeremy Ortiz and Giovanna Bendfeldt-Avila and Yi Xie and Mingyi Wang and Dongjing Wu and Herbert Higson and Elisa Lee and Kedest Teshome and Joaquin Barnoya and David E Kleiner and John Groopman and Roberto Orozco and Katherine A McGlynn and Eduardo Gharzouzi and Michael Dean
abstract: Background Guatemala has the highest incidence of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). the dominant type of liver cancer. in the Western Hemisphere. The major risk factors in Guatemala are not wellcharacterized. but the prevalence of hepatitis B (HBV) and hepatitis C virus (HCV) appear to be low. while the prevalence of aflatoxin (AFB 1) exposure appears to be high. To examine whether AFB 1 could be a risk factor for HCC in Guatemala. this study examined the frequency of the AFB 1-signature mutation in the TP53 gene (R249S) as well as other somatic mutations. Methods Ninety-one formalin-fixed. paraffin-embedded (FFPE) HCC tissues were obtained from three hospitals in Guatemala City. An additional. eighteen tumor tissues preserved in RNAlater were also obtained. Targeted sequencing of TP53 was successfully performed in 89 of the FFPE samples. and a panel of 245 genes were sequenced in the RNAlater samples. Results Overall. 47% of HCCs had a TP53 mutation. The AFB 1-signature R249S mutation was present in 24%. Among the RNAlater samples. 44% had any TP53 mutation and 33% had the R249S mutation. Other somatic mutations were identified in known HCC driver genes such as ARID1A. ARID2. and CTNNB1.Conclusions The presence of the TP53 R249S mutation indicates that AFB 1 is a risk factor for HCC in Guatemala. The proportion of HBV positive tumors was low. suggesting that AFB 1 is associated with HCC in the absence of concomitant HBV infection. To decrease the risk of HCC in Guatemala. AFB 1 abatements efforts are warranted.

title: The Role of Liver Biopsy in Drug-Induced Liver Injury
author: David E Kleiner
abstract: This review presents the current understanding of the role played by liver biopsy in the diagnosis and management of drug-induced liver injury (DILI).While liver biopsy remains an optional procedure in the evaluation of DILI. it has the potential to provide detailed information about the state of the liver. Recent histological surveys of DILI provide a framework for categorizing the patterns of injury that may be seen. Pattern information can be used to distinguish DILI from other potential causes of injury. both other acute injuries as well as pre-existing injury. The pattern of injury is related to differential diagnosis and in some cases can suggest a mechanism of injury. The character and severity of the injury could potentially be used in clinical decision-making. Examples of the use of liver biopsy in the context of DILI …

title: Mo1514–Platelets: A Powerful Tool for Cirrhosis Screening in Patients with Viral Hepatitis
author: Pallavi Surana and Varun Takyar and David Kleiner and Theo Heller and Christopher Koh
abstract: Background: In chronic liver disease. platelet counts have been used as surrogate marker in screening for portal hypertension and varices (ie Baveno VI criteria) or as a component of non-invasive fibrosis scores. Individually. platelet counts have not been used as a noninvasive marker for the identification of cirrhosis. Simple tools for clinicians to identify cirrhosis in patients with chronic viral hepatitis are medically necessary for the purposes of treatment initiation. hepatocellular cancer screening and additional medical management. Aims: To evaluate the clinical utility and performance of platelet counts in identifying cirrhosis in chronically infected viral hepatitis patients. Methods: Clinical. biochemical and histologic laboratory data from treatment naive chronic viral hepatitis B (HBV). C (HCV). and D (HDV) patients at the National Institutes of Health Clinical Center were evaluated. Laboratory values were collected …

title: Sa1527–Changes in Hepatic Gene Expression After Hcv Clearance and Their Association with Circulating Chemokine and Endotoxin Levels
author: Gabriella Quinn and Rabab Ali and Elizabeth Townsend and Grace Y Zhang and Kareen Hill and Ohad Etzion and Christopher Koh and Elliot Levy and David Kleiner and Theo Heller
abstract: Background: Direct-acting antiviral (DAA) therapy has revolutionized treatment for hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection. Little is known about the liver’s transcriptional alterations once HCV has cleared and inflammation has abated. Methods: 23 HCV patients were evaluated before and 1 year after Sofosbuvir/Velpatasvir treatment. All patients reached SVR after 12 weeks. Patients had liver biopsy with portal vein cannulation and portal blood samples were obtained. Peripheral blood and stool were also collected. Liver biopsies were scored for Ishak fibrosis (IF) and hepatic activity index (HAI). RNA-seq was performed on liver tissue. 16S rRNA metagenomics was performed on stool. Serum chemokines and microbial markers were measured via ELISA. Results: After HCV clearance. patients’ HAI scores decreased significantly (p< 1e-4) while IF scores did not. In a principal component analysis using liver transcriptome …

title: 407–The Delta-4 Score: A Novel and Clinically Useful Noninvasive Fibrosis Score for Hepatitis D
author: Ben L Da and Pallavi Surana and Varun Takyar and Christy Gilman and Anusha Vittal and Chunwei W Lai and David Kleiner and Elliot Levy and Theo Heller and Christopher Koh
abstract: Introduction: Non-invasive fibrosis markers including the AST to Platelet Ratio Index (APRI). Fibrosis-4 score (FIB-4). RDW to Platelet Ratio (RPR). and vibration controlled transient elastography (VCTE) have demonstrated clinical utility in fibrosis staging in patients with Hepatitis B (HBV) and Hepatitis C (HCV) virus infections. However. these markers have either demonstrated poor performance or have not been validated in HBV and Hepatitis D (HDV) co-infected patients. Aims: To develop a novel non-invasive fibrosis score to detect cirrhosis in patients with HBV/HDV co-infection. Methods: Chronic HBV. HCV. and HDV patients evaluated at the National Institutes of Health Clinical Center underwent VCTE. laboratory. imaging and histologic evaluation as clinically indicated. Cirrhosis was determined either by histology (Ishak fibrosis≥ 5) or by imaging consistent with cirrhosis with signs of portal hypertension (ie …

title: Su1082–Link Between Portal Venous Free Fatty Acids and Hepatic Lipid Metabolism in Chronic Hepatitis C Before and After Hcv Clearance
author: Rabab Ali and Gabriella Quinn and Kareen Hill and Grace Zhang and Christopher Koh and Elliot Levy and David Kleiner and Ohad Etzion and Theo Heller
abstract: Background: Primary biliary cholangitis (PBC). a chronic cholestatic autoimmune disease. can lead to progressive liver fibrosis. Biologic mechanisms contributing to PBC progression remain unclear. thus examination of novel patient factors are critical to advance understanding of disease pathogenesis and identify future treatment targets. Aims: To compare the fecal microbial communities between adult PBC patients with early vs. advanced fibrosis using culture-independent bacterial identification approaches. Methods: We performed a prospective analysis of the fecal microbiome in 15 PBC patients with early fibrosis (F2 fibrosis and lower) and 8 PBC patients with advanced fibrosis (F3 or more) on liver biopsy nearest study enrollment. Adult patients with accepted criteria for PBC diagnosis and documented compliance with ursodeoxycholic acid were enrolled. Data on demographics. laboratory tests. and clinical …

title: 409–Integration of the Fecal Metatranscriptome. Portal Vein Metabolome. and Liver Transcriptome in Order to Gain Insight Into the Microbiome's Importance in Hcv-Induced Liver …
author: Gabriella Quinn and Rabab Ali and Kareen Hill and Grace Zhang and Elizabeth Townsend and Ohad Etzion and Christopher Koh and Elliot Levy and David Kleiner and Theo Heller
abstract: Background: The role of the microbiome in chronic liver disease is of increasing interest. The microbiome’s contribution to the portal vein metabolome and how it is associated with disease severity in patients with HCV-induced liver injury has not been fully explored. Methods: 29 HCV patients were evaluated. All patients had liver biopsy with portal vein cannulation and portal blood samples were obtained. Peripheral blood and stool were also collected. Metabolomics was performed on serum samples to measure 1541 metabolites (Metabolon). RNA-seq was performed on fecal and liver samples. Using a weighted gene co-expression network analysis (WGCNA). expression data from the liver transcriptome. fecal metatranscriptome. and portal vein metabolome was clustered into three sets of modules. Results: The fecal metatranscriptome. liver transcriptome. and portal metabolome consisted of 20. 57. and 11 …

title: Innumerable Liver Lesions With a More Benign Outcome: A Case Report: 2398
author: Elie S Kazzi and Gil Ben-Yakov and David E Kleiner and Theo Heller
journal: Official journal of the American College of Gastroenterology| ACG
abstract: This case report sheds the light on a rare entity called hepatocellular adenomatosis: more than 10 adenomas in the absence of glycogen storage disease or anabolic steroid use. Our patient. a relatively healthy young woman. presented with an isolated rise of ALP. Physical examination revealed a woman with a body mass index of 38.8 Kg/m 2. The remaining physical examination was unremarkable. Transaminases were within normal levels. and viral hepatitis serology panel was negative. Magnetic resonance imaging using the hepatospecific contrast gadosetate (Figure 1) shows more than 10 nodular lesions that are heterogeneous. hyperintense at the periphery and hypointense in most of their center. The dynamic contrast-enhanced sequence is typical for a strong uptake on the arterial phase. followed by a washout on the delayed portal phase. These findings that are characteristic for adenomas. helping us …

title: Drug-Induced Liver Injury: Understanding the Different Immune-Mediated Phenotypes and Clinical Management
author: Ben L Da and Gil Ben-Yakov and David Kleiner and Christopher Koh
abstract: The aim of this manuscript is to review two immune-mediated drug-induced liver injury (DILI) phenotypes. immune-allergic DILI (IA-DILI) and DILI with autoimmune hepatitis features (DILI-AIH). which are poorly defined and can lead to significant morbidity and mortality.Recent information on this topic improves the understanding of IA-DILI and DILI-AIH regarding risk factors. associated medications. clinical presentations. histopathologic findings. and management strategies.Although the pathogenesis and specific mechanisms remain elusive. clinical and pathological advancements in our understanding of IA-DILI and DILI-AIH have provided clinicians with added tools for the diagnosis and management of these diseases. Further studies are needed to improve our …

title: Nonalcoholic Fatty Liver Disease (NAFLD) Outcome Post–Bariatric Surgery in the Teen-Longitudinal Assessment of Bariatric Surgery (Teen-LABS) Consortium
author: Fida Bacha and Resmi Gupta and Todd M Jenkins and Mary Brandt and Thomas H Inge and David Kleiner and Stavra Xanthakos
abstract: Teen-LABS is a multicenter. prospective observational study of adolescents undergoing bariatric surgery. Predictors of resolution of NAFLD post-surgery are unclear. We evaluated changes in serum ALT levels. an acceptable surrogate when liver biopsy is not feasible. in 219 Teen-LABS subjects 3 years post gastric bypass or vertical sleeve gastrectomy. Three years post-surgery. median BMI declined to 38.4 from 52.6 kg/m2 at baseline (p<0.01). Median ALT (IU/L) decreased between baseline (36.5 ± 2.6 [95% CI: 31.4. 41.7]) and 6 months after surgery (28.9 ± 2.5 [95% CI: 24.4. 33.9]). and remained stable at 1. 2 and 3 years. all p<0.01 vs. baseline. 58% had abnormal ALT at baseline. which decreased to 10% at 3 years. After adjustment by logistic regression. 6 month improvement in BMI. fasting glucose. HOMA-IR. triglycerides. TG/HDL. and HDL were independently associated with reduced ALT. Improvement in …

title: Sa1486-Modeling Histologic and Biochemical Improvements of Disease Severity in Chronic Hepatitis B Patients Treated with Long Term Nucleoside Analogues for Up to 18 Years and …
author: Pallavi Surana and Carly Broadwell and Devika Kapuria and Varun Takyar and Gil S Ben-Yakov and David Kleiner and Marc G Ghany and Jay Hoofnagle and Theo Heller and Christopher Koh
abstract: Results: Overall. there were 166.681 donors total. of whom 43.084 donors gave two or more donations. The overall prevalences of HBV. HCV. HIV and syphilis infections in the first time blood donors were 13.4%. 6.9%. 2.1% and 2.4%. respectively. The highest prevalence of concurrent infection was HBV and HCV with 1.713 (1.0%) donors. Other co-infections were less common with 528 (0.3%) donors with HBV-HIV. 561 (0.3%) donors with HBV-syphilis. and 238 (0.1%) donors with HCV-HIV co-infection. Of the four centers. Fada Ngourma had the highest HBV (17.4%). and HCV (9.5%) prevalences. For all centers combined. the prevalence of HBV infection was highest in the 20-25 age group (14.1%) and lowest in the 40-60 age group (1.3%). By contrast. HCV infection was highest in the greater than 60 year age group (15.4%) and lowest in the 25-40 year age group (5.9%). Among the repeat donors. the incidence rates of HBV. HCV. HIV. and syphilis infection were 2.43. 3.06. 1.12 and 1.29 per 100 person years. respectively. suggesting that there is a significant ongoing rate of acquisition of new blood-borne infections among adults in Burkina Faso. Conclusions: Burkina Faso had high HBV and HCV infection prevalences among blood donors. The HBV prevalence was relatively high in donors aged less than 40 years old. The differences in prevalences in different age groups suggest that the results from screening of blood donors. particularly older individuals. may not represent the actual prevalences of blood-borne infections in the population. Possibly. individuals who were previously excluded from donation because they tested positive at a …

title: Mo1470-The Relationship of Quantitative Hepatitis B Surface Antigen (QHBSAG) and E Antigen (Qhbeag) Levels to Liver Histology in HBV-HIV Coinfection: Results from the HBV-HIV …
author: Richard K Sterling and Abdus Wahed and Wendy King and David Kleiner and Mandana Khalili and Mark S Sulkowski and Mamta K Jain and Mauricio Lisker-Melman and David Wong and Raymond T Chung and Marc G Ghany
abstract: Background: Patients with chronic hepatitis C (CHC) frequently suffer from pain and often have a prior history of substance use disorders. As a result. they may have high rates of prescription opioid use with potential for opioid misuse. However. patterns and clinical impact of prescription opioid use among patients with CHC are unknown. Methods: A national insurance database (Marketscan Commercial and Medicare Supplemental Database) was used to identify commercially insured patients with CHC who sought care between January 2010 and June 2015. The first CHC ICD9 code found during this time period was used as their index date. We conducted three analyses:(1) prevalence of opioid prescriptions among patients with CHC and patterns of use.(2) evaluation of risk factors for opioid prescriptions (yes/no) in patients with CHC. and (3) clinical outcomes associated with opioid prescriptions. All patients in the analysis had active prescription coverage for a minimum of 12 months before the index date and 6 months after the index date. Opioid use was defined as having received any prescription fill for opioids. Opioid use was further classified as prior chronic (at least 120-day supply or more than 3 prescription opioids within 365 days before the index date). prior intermittent (non-chronic use before index date) or naïve (new opioid use after index date). Results: We identified of 72.613 CHC patients with a mean age of 53. 61% male (Table 1). The prevalence of opioid use during this period was 73%. Among these patients. 15.4% were prior chronic users. 37.1% prior intermittent users. and 20.2% naïve users. The most common form of …

title: Su1551-Low Skeletal Muscle Mass is Associated with Advanced Steatosis in Non Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease
author: Devika Kapuria and Firas Ghomraoui and Phil Brown and Gil S Ben-Yakov and David Kleiner and Yaron Rotman
abstract: Background: Sarcopenia has been associated with poor clinical outcomes in cirrhotics. including survival. quality of life and post-transplant outcomes. The association of sarcopenia with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is still under debate. Decreased muscle mass is associated with insulin resistance. which could provide a causal link to NAFLD. However. a direct contribution of sarcopenia towards NAFLD has yet not been reported. Aim: To determine whether muscle mass is associated with histological features of NAFLD across the spectrum of disease. independently of shared risk factors. Methods: We performed a retrospective analysis of adult patients with biopsy-proven NAFLD. Bilateral psoas muscle area was measured at L3-L4 on abdominal MRI and normalized by height to obtain the psoas muscle index (PMI). which represents skeletal muscle mass. Liver biopsies were scored using the NASH-CRN system. The association of PMI with histological scores was assessed using univariate and multivariate analyses. with age. HOMA-IR. weight and gender as covariates. In a subset of 19 subjects. insulin sensitivity and glucose disposition were measured by an intravenous glucose tolerance test (IVGTT) and appendicular skeletal mass was measured by DEXA. Results: We studied 60 patients. 35 (58%) males. aged 45.8±13 years. 39 subjects (65%) were obese and median ALT was 61 U/L. 13 (22%) patients had advanced steatosis (grade 3). 45 (75%) patients had steatohepatitis and 2 (3%) had cirrhosis. The average PMI for the group was 584±196 cm2/m2 and was correlated with appendicular skeletal muscle mass by DEXA (r= 0 …

title: Mo1416-Changes in Portal and Peripheral Cytokines Following Hepatitic C Virus Clearance; A Window Into the Link Between Liver Disease and Host Immunity
author: Rabab Ali and Lisa Scheuing and Gabriella Quinn and Kareen Hill and Grace Zhang and Elizabeth Townsend and Christopher Koh and Elliot B Levy and David Kleiner and Ohad Etzion and Theo Heller
abstract: Background: HCV is associated with altered immunity which is compounded by the resultant liver disease. This is now being studied in the peripheral serum of HCV patients after direct acting antiviral therapy. The liver modulates immune responses and receives immune signals via portal vein. Portal vein evaluation may be important to understand the link between HCV induced liver disease and associated immune changes that may persist in the absence of HCV. We aim to investigate immune changes in portal and peripheral serum before and after HCV clearance. Methods: Prospectively enrolled HCV patients had a liver biopsy with portal vein cannulation (LBPVC); portal and peripheral blood was obtained both before {phase 1 (P1)} and 1 year after Sofosbuvir/Velpatasvir therapy {phase 2 (P2)}. Ishak fibrosis (IF) and hepatic activity index (HAI) was used to score fibrosis and inflammation. ELISAs assessed cytokines. chemokines. macrophage and endothelial markers. Results: 23 patients had LBPVC in P1 and P2. 14 were non-cirrhotic {Ishak Fibrosis (IF) 0-4} and 9 compensated cirrhotic (IF 5-6). All achieved SVR12. Wilcoxon matched-pairs test was used to compare P1 and P2. In P2. there was a decrease in HAI (p< 0.0001) but no change in IF. Among inflammatory and type 1 cytokines (T1); portal and peripheral IL8. TNF alpha. TNF beta. IL12p40. and CXCL10; peripheral IL6. and portal sCD14; all decreased in P2 (all p< 0.05). Portal IL2 and IL12p70 increased with no change in periphery. For type 2 cytokines (T2). portal levels of IL4. CCL17. and CCL22 increased. and IL13 and IL1RL1 remain unchanged in P2. In the periphery. only …

title: Mo1447-Bile Duct Damage and Cirrhosis in Primary Biliary Cholangitis: An Investigation of Non-Invasive Biomarkers
author: Natasha Kamal and Pallavi Surana and Mazen Noureddin and David Kleiner and Jay Hoofnagle and Theo Heller and Christopher Koh
abstract: Background: A key pathogenesis of Primary Biliary Cholangitis (PBC) involves damage to intrahepatic bile ducts. While the utility of non-invasive fibrosis markers have been demonstrated in PBC. optimal cutoffs have not been studied and non-invasive methods of identifying biliary damage need further exploration. Aims: To identify disease-specific cut-offs for cirrhosis with non-invasive fibrosis markers and to explore biomarkers that can identify significant biliary damage (> 50% bile duct loss) in PBC. Methods: Patients with PBC managed at the NIH Clinical Center from 1979-2010 were retrospectively evaluated. Pretreatment anthropometrics. laboratory and histologic data were analyzed. Bile duct loss fraction (BDLF) was calculated by [1-(# of portal areas with damaged ducts/total# of portal areas identified)] and copper was scored on a 0-3 scale. The performances of the aspartate aminotransferase (AST) to alanine aminotransferase (ALT) ratio (AAR). AST to platelet ratio index (APRI). and Fibrosis-4 score (FIB-4) were compared to predict histological data. Results: Eightyfive predominantly female (88%) PBC patients with a mean age of 50 years (range 23-68) were evaluated. 84% were Caucasians. 5% Blacks. 5% Hispanics. and 4% Asians. Mean laboratory values (SD) included: alkaline phosphatase (ALP)= 574U/L (631). gammaglutamyl transferase (GGT)= 565U/L (414). total bilirubin (TB)= 1.53 mg/dL (2.84). platelets= 253K/µL (95). Median Ishak fibrosis score was 2 (1-3). On average. patients with Ishak≥ 3 lost 57% of their bile ducts and patients with Ishak≥ 5 lost 87%. BDLF significantly correlated with ALP (r= 0.48. p< 0.0001). GGT (r= 0 …

title: Mo1491-Fibroscan in Sickle Cell Liver Disease-Could we Strike while the Liver is Hard?
author: Gil S Ben-Yakov and Hawwa Alao and Pallavi Surana and Devika Kapuria and Ohad Etzion and Matthew M Hsieh and John F Tisdale and Fitzhugh D Courtney and David Kleiner and Elliot B Levy and Chang F Richard and Elenita F Rivera and Amy Huang and Christopher Koh and Theo Heller
abstract: Background & Aims: Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) is a progressive inflammatory process that leads to bile duct blockage and hepatic fibrosis. Interestingly. PSC occurs twice as frequently in men than women. The liver has a unique lymphocytic profile with up to 50% of total lymphocytes represented by natural killer (NK) cells. When NK cells are activated in the liver. they can cause liver injury by directly killing hepatocytes and biliary epithelial cells. In addition. they release chemokines and cytokines which contribute to chronic inflammation. potentially exacerbating disease. Two classes of NK cells have been identified. residential and infiltrating NK cells. but little is currently known about their roles in hepatic immunity. In this study. we investigate gender differences in infiltrating and residential hepatic NK cells in the MDR2-/-mouse model of PSC. Methods: Hepatic mononuclear cells were isolated from the livers of eleven-week-old male and female MDR2-/-and age-and gender-matched control C57BL/6J mice. We developed a panel of antibodies to characterize both hepatic residential and infiltrating NK cells. Flow cytometry was used to analyze NK cell levels. maturation status and phenotype in our PSC model. Results: Total liver-derived NK cells were identified by the expression of NKp46/NCR1 while the expression pattern of integrins (CD49a and CD49b) on total NK cells distinguished resident and infiltrating hepatic NK cell subsets. Female MDR2-/-mice had a significantly higher proportion of residential NK cells and less infiltrating NK cells when compared to their male counterparts. The majority of liver-resident NK cells have an …

title: 362-Development of Non-Cirrhotic Portal Hypertension Increases Mortality Risk in at Risk Populations
author: Ben L Da and Pallavi Surana and Devika Kapuria and Rehan Farooqi and Peace Aminu and Courtney Fitzhugh and John Tisdale and Matthew Hsieh and Elliot B Levy and David Kleiner and Steven Holland and Elizabeth Garabedian and Theo Heller and Christopher Koh
abstract: Introduction: Non-cirrhotic portal hypertension (NCPH) encompasses a heterogeneous group of liver diseases defined by the development of portal hypertension and its sequalae. in the absence of cirrhosis. Despite various descriptions of the disease. mostly in developing countries. the natural history of NCPH and its impact on mortality is relatively unknown. Aims: To study the clinical course of subjects with NCPH and identify factors that may be associated with mortality. Methods: Patients with primary diseases known to be associated with the development of NCPH who were enrolled in 1 of 18 natural history protocols from 1998-2017 at the NIH Clinical Center were retrospectively evaluated. All patients underwent clinical liver biopsies. and when indicated. hepatic venous pressure gradient measurements. Subjects were classified as having NCPH or" at risk" for developing NCPH based on clinical results. Patients were routinely followed from the time of the first liver biopsy to their last visit or mortality. Logistic regression analysis was used to determine factors associated with mortality. Results: Of the 122 patients evaluated. 83 (68%) were males with a median follow up of 3.78 years (IQR: 1.02-7.03). 50 (41%) had primary immunodeficiencies. 43 (35%) had sickle cell disease and 29 (24%) had other diseases. 66 (54%) had NCPH and were older than those" at risk"(39.3 vs 32.2 years. p= 0.02). At baseline. those with NCPH had higher; alkaline phosphatase (ALP; 220 vs 115 U/L. p< 0.0001). aspartate aminotransferase (AST; 57 vs 44 U/L. p= 0.028). and hematocrit (HCT; 35 vs 29%. p< 0.0001) with lower; albumin (3.4 vs 3.8 g/dL. p= 0.003). total …

title: Tu1539-Vibration Controlled Elastography Predicts Severity of Portal Hypertension in Non Cirrhotic Portal Hypertension
author: Devika Kapuria and Christopher Koh and Shilpa Lingala and Gil S Ben-Yakov and Ben L Da and Courtney Fitzhugh and Ivan J Fuss and Matthew Hsieh and Amy Huang and David Kleiner and Theo Heller
abstract: BACKGROUND: Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC) is the fastest growing cause of cancer related death in the United States. Detection of early stage HCC allows for potential curative treatments to improve survival and outcomes. Due to increase in life expectancy of the general population. the number of individuals with HCC aged 70 and older has been rising. Studies have reported improvement in survival of elderly cirrhotic patients by increasing the percentage of HCC amenable to effective treatments. AIM: To evaluate the compliance of surveillance for HCC in elderly individuals. METHODS: We retrospectively reviewed the medical records (demographics. etiology of liver disease. comorbidities. HCC surveillance. characteristics. treatments and outcomes) of all patients with HCC at Northwell Health between January 1st 2013 and July 31st 2017. We included patients diagnosed with HCC at age 70 and older. They were grouped into age 70-79 years (group A). and 80 years and older (group B) with a follow-up duration of 12 months after diagnosis. RESULTS: A total of 108 out of 324 patients were aged 70 and older (32%) at the time of HCC diagnosis. Thirty seven percent (n= 40) were in group A and 73%(n= 68) in group B. Patient characteristics are listed in table 1. Metastatic HCC occurred in 50%(n= 20) of group A and 31%(n= 21) of group B (p= 0.041). Forty two percent (n= 41) of those with cirrhosis (n= 98) had standard surveillance for HCC every 6 months. and 58%(n= 57) had suboptimal surveillance (ranging 7 to 18 months; mean 12±4 months). Standard HCC surveillance was performed in 40% for group A compared to 43% for group B …

title: Gene signature of HDV-associated hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC): differences with HCC associated with other hepatitis viruses
author: G Diaz and RE Engle and A Nice and M Melis and S Montenegro and J Rodriguez-Canale and J Hanson and MR Emmert-Buck and F Zamboni and S Govindarajan and DE Kleiner and P Farci
abstract: SAT-190 Gene signature of HDV-associated hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC): differences with HCC associated with other hepatitis viruses G. Diaz1. RE Engle2. A. Nice2. M. Melis2. S. title: Assessment of conjugated. primary and secondary bile acids in the portal venous system across the spectrum of chronic HCV associated liver disease; link to inflammation and …
author: R Ali and G Zhang and E Townsend and C Koh and E Levy and DE Kleiner and O Etzion and T Heller
abstract: FRI-252 Assessment of conjugated. primary and secondary bile acids in the portal venous system across the spectrum of chronic HCV associated liver disease; link to inflammation and microbial products R. Ali. G. Zhang. E. Townsend. C. Koh. E. Levy. DE Kleiner. O. Etzion. T. Heller. National Institutes of Health. Translational Hepatology Section. NIDDK. Bethesda. United States Email:[email protected] Background and Aims: There is growing evidence of the critical role bile acids (BA) play in chronic liver disease. particularly in the crosstalk between the diseased liver and gut microbiome. Altered BA conjugation and hydroxylation are potential mechanisms modulating the gut-liver axis and may contribute to disease progression. The relative proportions of BA metabolites in the portal vein have not been well explored. The aim of this study was to characterize BA in association with liver injury and immune markers in …

title: Tremelimumab in combination with microwave ablation in patients with refractory biliary tract cancer (BTC).
author: Changqing Xie and Suzanne Fioravanti and Melissa Walker and Donna Mabry and David E Kleiner and Brad J Wood and Elliot B Levy and Venkatesh P Krishnasamy and Seth M Steinberg and Austin G Duffy and Tim F Greten
abstract: 365Background: Treatment option for patients with advanced BTC is limited and prognosis is poor with a median survival of less than 1 year in the locally advanced or metastatic setting. It has been shown deregulation of the immune system plays an important role in the pathogenesis of BTC. This study aimed to investigate whether tremelimumab (Treme). anti-CTLA4. could be combined safely and feasibly with microwave ablation therapy to enhance the effect of anti-CTLA4 treatment in patients with advanced BTC. Methods: Patients with refractory BTC were enrolled in a study of monthly Treme (10mg/kg. IV. 6 doses). followed by 3-monthly infusions until off-treatment criteria were met. On day 36. patients underwent subtotal microwave ablation. Staging image was performed every 8 weeks. Adverse events (AEs) were collected and managed. Tumor samples and peripheral blood samples were collected to perform …

title: Mounier-Kuhn Syndrome Mimicking Lymphangioleiomyomatosis
author: Gustavo G Pacheco and Amanda M Jones and Jianhua Yao and David E Kleiner and Angelo M Taveira-DaSilva and Joel Moss
abstract: We present the case of a man with Mounier-Kuhn syndrome (MKS). or tracheobronchomegaly. who was referred to the National Institutes of Health Clinical Research Center because of a potential diagnosis of lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM). a rare condition in men. The patient was evaluated using ongoing protocols and provided written informed consent. The case demonstrates the presence of chronic inflammation surrounding the dilated airways and histologic changes of the lung parenchyma with emphysematouslike disruption in areas adjacent to the dilated airways. This finding suggests that damage to the lung parenchyma is an ongoing phenomenon in MKS. Moreover. our analysis of CT images indicates similar abnormalities in areas remote from the dilated airways. Finally. because of increased anatomic dead space. calculation of lung diffusion capacity by the single-breath method yielded abnormally …

title: Apobec-mutagenesis drives mutational heterogeneity while copy number alterations drive transcriptomic and proteogenomic heterogeneity in metastatic lung adenocarcinoma and …
author: Nitin Roper and James Gao and Rouf Banday and Tapan Maity and Xu Zhang and Abhilash Venugopalan and Rajesh Patidar and Sivasish Sindiri and Constance Cultraro and Alexandr Goncearenco and Anna Panchenko and Romi Biswas and Jing Wang and Stephen Hewitt and David Kleiner and Bing Zhang and Javed Khan and Ludmila Prokunina-Olsson and Udayan Guha

title: Abstract A182: Apobec-mutagenesis drives mutational heterogeneity while copy number alterations drive transcriptomic and proteogenomic heterogeneity in metastatic lung …
author: Nitin Roper and James Gao and Rouf Banday and Tapan Maity and Xu Zhang and Abhilash Venugopalan and Rajesh Patidar and Sivasish Sindiri and Constance Cultraro and Alexandr Goncearenco and Anna Panchenko and Romi Biswas and Jing Wang and Stephen Hewitt and David Kleiner and Bing Zhang and Javed Khan and Ludmila Prokunina-Olsson and Udayan Guha
abstract: Background: Molecular characterization of metastatic tumors to investigate intra- and intertumor heterogeneity has proven more difficult than early stage disease as opportunities for surgical removal are limited. Rapid/warm autopsy programs that are conducted soon after death minimize tissue ischemia. thereby enabling procurement of high-quality viable tissue. To our knowledge. integrated proteo-genomics studies to characterize tumor heterogeneity of metastatic lung adenocarcinoma and thymic carcinoma are lacking. Methods: We sought to characterize and decipher mechanisms of intra- and intertumor heterogeneity of Stage IV lung adenocarcinoma and thymic carcinoma through whole exome sequencing. RNA sequencing. copy number estimation. and mass spectrometry-based proteomics of 38 tumors from five rapid/warm autopsy patients. The autopsy procedure was initiated between 2-4 hours of death …

title: Integrated proteogenomic analysis of metastatic thoracic tumors identifies APOBEC mutagenesis and copy number alterations as drivers of proteogenomic tumor evolution and …
author: Nitin Roper and Shaojian Gao and Tapan K Maity and A Rouf Banday and Xu Zhang and Abhilash Venugopalan and Constance M Cultraro and Rajesh Patidar and Sivasish Sindiri and Alexandr Goncearenco and Anna R Panchenko and Romi Biswas and Anish Thomas and Arun Rajan and Corey A Carter and David Kleiner and Stephen Hewitt and Javed Khan and Ludmila Prokunina-Olsson and Udayan Guha
abstract: Elucidation of the proteogenomic evolution of metastatic tumors may offer insight into the poor prognosis of patients harboring metastatic disease. We performed whole-exome and transcriptome sequencing. copy number alterations (CNA) and mass spectrometry-based quantitative proteomics of 37 lung adenocarcinoma (LUAD) and thymic carcinoma (TC) metastases obtained by rapid autopsy and found evidence of patient-specific. multi-dimensional heterogeneity. Extreme mutational heterogeneity was evident in a subset of patients whose tumors showed increased APOBEC-signature mutations and expression of APOBEC3 region transcripts compared to patients with lesser mutational heterogeneity. TP53 mutation status was associated with APOBEC hypermutators in our cohort and in three independent LUAD datasets. In a thymic carcinoma patient. extreme heterogeneity and increased APOBEC3AB expression was associated with a high-risk germline APOBEC3AB variant allele. Patients with CNA occurring late in tumor evolution had corresponding changes in gene expression and protein abundance indicating genomic instability as a mechanism of downstream transcriptomic and proteomic heterogeneity between metastases. Across all tumors. proteomic heterogeneity was greater than copy number and transcriptomic heterogeneity. Enrichment of interferon pathways was evident both in the transcriptome and proteome of the tumors enriched for APOBEC mutagenesis despite a heterogeneous immune microenvironment across metastases suggesting a role for the immune microenvironment in the expression of APOBEC transcripts and …

title: Tumor Heterogeneity Analyzes by Integrated Proteo-Genomics of Thoracic Tumors from Sequential Biopsies and Warm Autopsies
author: N Roper and X Zhang and T Maity and S Gao and A Venugopalan and R Biswas and C Cultraro and C Kim and E Padiernos and A Rajan and A Thomas and R Hassan and D Kleiner and S Hewitt and J Khan and U Guha

title: P1. 02-063 Tumor Heterogeneity Analyzes by Integrated Proteo-Genomics of Thoracic Tumors from Sequential Biopsies and Warm Autopsies
author: N Roper and X Zhang and T Maity and S Gao and A Venugopalan and R Biswas and C Cultraro and C Kim and E Padiernos and A Rajan and A Thomas and R Hassan and D Kleiner and S Hewitt and J Khan and U Guha
abstract: BackgroundTumor heterogeneity modulates treatment response to targeted therapy. Both intra-tumor and inter-tumor heterogeneity is well characterized in various cancers. including lung cancer. the commonest cause of cancer death in both men and women. Tumor heterogeneity studies have been conducted mostly for early stage lung cancer. Furthermore. these studies have focused primarily on next-generation sequencing (NGS).MethodWe applied whole exome sequencing (WES). RNA-seq. CNV-seq and mass spectrometry-based proteomic analyses on 33 tumor regions from metastatic sites including lung. liver and kidney. obtained by rapid/warm autopsy from 4 patients with Stage IV lung adenocarcinoma. The autopsy procedure was initiated between 2-4 hours of death.Results: We found considerable intertumor …

abstract: Hepatic sinusoidal obstructive syndrome (SOS). sometimes known as hepatic veno-occlusive disease (VOD). is a known complication and generally occurs as an acute process following hematopoietic stem cell transplant. SOS is occasionally difficult to diagnose and to differentiate from GvHD. Treatments of SOS are limited to supportive care and defibrotide. a recently FDA-approved medication indicated for SOS with multi-organ failure. 1 Although early recognition of SOS may improve outcomes. 2 optimal diagnostic and prognostic testing of SOS remains undefined. Here. we report two cases of SOS following haplo-identical stem cell transplantation and their clinical correlations with plasma biomarkers of SOS.Both patients were enrolled on a clinical protocol approved by our institutional review board (14-H-0180. NCT02226861 and 94-H-0010. NCT00001397) after obtaining informed consent. including the use …

abstract: 9023Background: Intratumor heterogeneity has been characterized among multiple cancer types. In lung adenocarcinoma. APOBEC-mutagenesis has been shown to be a source of heterogeneity. However. these data are largely limited to early stage primary tumors. Methods: We applied whole exome sequencing. RNA-seq. title: Pattern of Hepatitis B Virus (HBV) Core Antigen (HBCAG+) and Surface Antigen (HBSAG) Staining in Patients Co-Infected with Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV)
author: Richard K Sterling and Abdus Wahed and Mandana Khalili and Mark S Sulkowski and Mamta Jain and David Wong and Mauricio Lisker-Melman and Marc G Ghany and Raymond T Chung and David Kleiner
abstract: Background Hepatitis B virus (HBV) is a major cause of acute and chronic liver diseases. HBV affects an estimated 350 million individuals globally. and it is responsible for 600.000 premature deaths annually. While the aggregate rate of HBV infection has been steadily decreasing in the United States (US). some minority groups continue to experience high infection risks. At the same time. foreign-born US residents who come from countries with high HBV prevalence are at high risk for the sequelae of chronic HBV. due to lack of virus screening and vaccination overseas. This study aims to investigate the interaction between nativity and race as predictors of HBV vaccination status through analysis of data from the 2015 National Health Interview Survey (NHIS). Methods The study sample included 30.559 adults aged 18 to 85 who participated in the 2015 NHIS. The NHIS is an annual health survey that is representative of the non-institutionalized US population. The main outcome of interest was HBV vaccination status. Multivariable logistic regression models adjusting for age. education. self-reported health status. region of residence. health insurance access and gender were fitted to examine the association between nativity. race and vaccination status. Adjusted logistic regression models that included a race-by-nativity cross-product term were fitted to assess the presence of interaction between race and nativity. Sampling weights were applied to yield nationally representative prevalence and effect estimates. P-values less than 0.05 were considered indicative of statistical significance. Results An estimated 30.38%(95% CI; 29.54%. 31.22%) of …

abstract: Background: Persons with IBD and their providers use the term ‘flare'to loosely define an increase in symptoms. Instruments used to identify an IBD flare are limited. Aims: A casecontrol study to assess the relationship between a 7-point indicator used to identify a flare and 5 measures of disease activity: fecal calprotectin (FCAL≥ 250). a 2-point scale defining IBD as inactive/active. a 4-point scale used for self-reporting a flare (not. possibly. probably or definitely in a flare). a newly developed symptom index the Short IBD Symptom Index (SIBDSI). and the short form IBDQ (SIBDQ). Methods: Persons 18-75 yrs.. living in Manitoba with IBD (n= 135) completed surveys every 2 weeks for 1 yr. A flare was identified using a score≥ 6 on a 7-point measure of change in symptoms over time. Subjects who flared were matched to controls who had never flared based on date of enrolment. matched by sex. and disease type. Chi …

abstract: Conclusions: Independently of the criteria used for diagnosis. and despite relatively frequent peaks of HBV-DNA during FU. ICs and GZ patients have an excellent long-term prognosis and a relatively high rate of HBsAg loss. The use of a restrictive IC definition (AASLD guidelines) does not seem to add a benefit regarding prognosis and may increase the need for liver biopsies as well as more follow-up visits.

abstract: A 14-year-old Inuit female presented with a history of persistent Epstein Barr (EBV) viremia and EBV hepatitis. She had intermittent fevers with abdominal discomfort. She reported a diet rich in seal meat and significant recent weight gain. Her BMI was 29 and abdominal examination revealed tenderness in the right hypochondrium with hepatomegaly.Laboratory exam was notable for Alkaline Phosphatase 178U/L (50–162 U/L). Alanine Aminotransferase 98U/L (5–30U/L). Aspartate Aminotransferase 95 U/L (0–40U/L). bilirubin total< 0.2 mg/dl (0–1.2 mg/dl). albumin 3.9 (3.5–5g/dl). platelet 209 K/uL (173–369 K/ul). Total Cholesterol 141 mg/dl (0–169 mg/dl). Triglycerides 145 mg/dl (0–149mg/dl). Low Density Lipoprotein 65 mg/dl. Glucose 105 mg/dl (74–106mg/dl). Cytomegalovirus negative. EBV 6.13 log10 IU/ml. Hepatitis B surface antigen negative. Hepatitis C virus antibody negative.

Patients were treated with tremelimumab. another anti-CTLA4 mAb. and tumor ablation (radiofrequency ablation. cryoablation. and transcatheter arterial chemoembolization) to augment anti-tumor immunity. Peripheral blood mononuclear cells. viral load (HBV/HCV) and tumor biopsies were studied and clinical efficacy was correlated with immune monitoring results.Methods: Patients with HCC were enrolled in a study of tremelimumab combined with tumor ablation performed on week 6. Tumor biopsies were performed at baseline and at time of RFA/TACE and analyzed by immunohistochemistry. Gene expression analysis was …

title: 9 When is it NAFLD and when is it ALD?: Can the histologic evaluation of a liver biopsy guide the clinical evaluation?
author: Elizabeth M Brunt and David E Kleiner
journal: Clinical Dilemmas in Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease
abstract: Most pathology literature and nearly all clinical literature related to fatty liver disease comment that alcoholic and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease are indistinguishable histologically. In fact. this was the basis for the appellation offatty liver disease related to obesity in patients without significant alcohol consumption. an unfortunate “non‐” term. This may be true of steatosis and of mild forms of steatohepatitis. but pathologists have noted features that may distinguish the two. particularly in the severe form of ALD [1. 2]. These include lesions to the outflow veins described from the earliest work in ALD [3]. as well as canalicular cholestasis [4]. a lesion included in a new scoring system for alcoholic hepatitis [5]. but not a feature of NASH. In this chapter. we review the primary lesions of both alcoholic and non-alcoholic fatty liver diseases as well as features that may be unique or more common in one compared to the other. A review of the literature of comparative studies summarized conclusions of investigators that the shared lesions are often more “severe” in the severe forms of ALD [2]. Further. clinical context is essential in biopsy interpretation. Finally. grading systems for both have been published [6. 7]; the former was developed primarily for comparinglesions for clinical trials. while the latter was for prognostication for alcoholic hepatitis. The lesions utilized in these systems are a reflection of significant features. and therefore both shared and different histopathologic features of these entities can be regarded as differing histologic manifestations. Table 9.1 shows a summary of shared and differinglesions of ALD and NAFLD. most of which are …

abstract: Objective: Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is the most common cause of chronic liver disease in children in the United States. Studies have suggested a possible connection between birth weight and conditions that are risk factors for NAFLD such as obesity or insulin resistance. We hypothesized that birth weights at both tails of the normal curve. either low or high. influence the risk for NAFLD. The study aims were to evaluate: 1) the distribution of birth weight in children with NAFLD compared to the general US population and 2) the relationship between birth weight and severity of NAFLD. Methods: We included children with biopsy-proven NAFLD enrolled in the NASH CRN. Liver biopsies were reviewed centrally by the Pathology Committee. Birth weights were recorded and categorized as: low (LBW). 1.500 to 2.499 gm; normal (NBW). 2.500 to 3.999 gm; or high (HBW).≥ 4.000 gm. The distribution of birth …

abstract: Background & Aims: The liver plays important roles in glucose and lipid metabolism. Both glucose intolerance and dyslipidemia are components of the metabolic syndrome. Fatty liver is also considered as a phenotype of the metabolic syndrome in the liver. We aimed to confirm the association of fatty liver with glucose intolerance and dyslipidemia in a longitudinal study. We evaluated also the association of other factors with glucose intolerance and dyslipidemia. Methods: We obtained clinical and laboratory data from 7.332 Japanese who had a systematic health checkup at Junpukai Health Maintenance Center in 2007. Individuals with concurrent liver disease. those with any missing components of data. and those without follow-up study between 2008 and 2010 were excluded. Finally. we analyzed 4.349 individuals (2.623 men and 1.726 women; median age. 48 years; a total of 13.957 observations) to estimate …

author: Hawwa Alao and David Kleiner and Ma Ai Thanda Han and Varun Takyar and Deborah Stone and Patrycja Hoffmann and Amanda Ombrello and Anne Jones and Daniel Kastner and Theo Heller
abstract: Background: Recent data in adults suggest that nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is independently associated with extrahepatic complications such as cardiovascular disease and diabetes. The aim of the current study was to evaluate the prevalence of these complications in a group of children with biopsy-proven NAFLD and assess their association with the histologic al severity of NAFLD. Methods: Consecutive children who presented to our clinic for evaluation of NAFLD and had a liver biopsy were included. The diagnosis of nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) and the scoring of its individual histological features were done by an experienced pathologist. Patients with NAFLD were divided into two groups: NASH and" not NASH". Data on the following complications were collected: hypertension. masked hypertension (based on ambulatory blood pressure monitoring). ventricular abnormality (based on …

title: Plasma Osteopontin Is a Biomarker Specifically Associated with Bronchiolitis Obliterans Syndrome after HCT
author: Kirsten M Williams and Fran T Hakim and Avi Rosenberg and David Kleiner and Sandra A Mitchell and Michael Tamm and Daniele Avila and Stephanie J Lee and Joerg Halter and Spasenija Savic Prince and Lukas Bubendorf and Catherine M Bollard and Steven Z Pavletic and Ronald Gress
journal: Biology of Blood and Marrow Transplantation
abstract: BackgroundBronchiolitis obliterans syndrome (BOS) is a rare complication after allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplant (HCT) and confers high mortality. BOS is difficult to diagnosis and a plasma biomarker specific for this form of chronic graft-vs.-host disease (cGVHD) would be invaluable. Osteopontin is produced by alternative alveolar macrophages both after radiation. chemotherapy. and may be up-regulated during remodeling and fibrotic pulmonary injury. We hypothesized that osteopontin would be elevated in patients with BOS after HCT if this alternative activation pathway of alveolar macrophages causes BOS after HCT.MethodsPlasma biomarkers were measured in batches using protein array analysis in 124 patients with cGVHD collected in multiple prospective IRB-approved studies. BOS was diagnosed by the modified NIH consensus criteria (FEV1< 75% predicted. FEV1/VC< 0.7 or biopsy proven …

H3K27me3). active enhancers (H3K27ac) and Polycomb-repressed regions (H3K27me3) in HCV-infected cells compared to mock-infected controls. Results: Based on an analysis of approximately 25.000 human transcription start sites (TSS). we observed a strong virus-induced increase in the H3K27ac marks as well as a decrease in H3K4me3 marks on a genome-wide level. Interestingly. HCV infection induced marked epigenetic changes at loci of genes that constitute a clinical risk signature predictive of HCC development in patients with liver disease. abstract: Method: The DILIN database of adjudicated cases enrolled from 2004 to March 2015 (1499 cases) were reviewed for Move Free® implicated DILI as described (Gastroenterology 135: 1924).Results: Four cases of liver injury attributed to Move Free® were enrolled between 2010 and 2014; 1 scored as very likely and 2 as probable with one awaiting adjudication. All 4 were adult female who rapidly developed acute hepatitis with autoantibodies after relatively short exposure (< 4 weeks) in 3 out of the 4 cases (Table). Liver biopsies done in 3 subjects revealed changes consistent with immune mediated injury with inflammatory infiltrates of lymphocytic and plasma cells.Conclusions: DILI associated with Move Free® presented with rapid development of acute hepatitis with autoantibodies and inflammatory cells on liver biopsy strongly suggests immune mediated liver injury possibly in predisposed autoimmune hepatitis …

author: Laetitia Canini and Christopher Koh and Scott J Cotler and Xiongce Zhao and Susan L Uprichard and Vanessa Haynes-Williams and Mark A Winters and Gitanjali Subramanya and SL Cooper and Peter Pinto and Erin Wolff and Rachel Bishop and MA Than Han and David E Kleiner and Onur Keskin and Ramazan Idilman and Cihan Yurdaydin and Jeffrey S Glenn and Theo Heller and Harel Dahari
abstract: Introduction: ACLF is characterized by acute deterioration of liver function in subjects with liver cirrhosis. Commonly precipitated by an acute event. it is associated with extra-hepatic organ failure leading to high in-hospital mortality dependent on severity despite maximal support of failing organs. Serum markers of caspasedriven apoptosis are raised in ACLF subjects. Emricasan is an orally active caspase inhibitor with demonstrated efficacy in animal models of liver disease. Emricasan inhibits caspases involved in the maturation of pro-inflammatory cytokines. IL-1b and IL-18. We studied the PK/PD and safety of emricasan and its effect on caspase activity and apoptosis in subjects with ACLF. Material and Methods: 21 Subjects with ACLF-1 and-2 were randomised to receive oral emricasan 5 (n= 5). 25 (n= 7) and 50 mg (n= 5). or pbo (n= 4) BID for 28 days. Full PK/PD profiles were obtained on Days 1. 4 and 28. Clinical responders as defined in the table were evaluated at Day 28 or last known follow up. Results: 7 subjects completed the study: pbo (n= 2). 25 (n= 3) and 50mg (n= 2). 6 subjects died [pbo (n= 2). 5 (n= 1). 25 (n= 1) and 50mg (n= 2) respectively] by Day 28; 13/21 subjects reported serious AEs. none of which were considered treatment related. Emricasan blood levels were increased at all doses compared to previous patient populations studied. Baseline values of cCK18 and Caspase 3/7 were significantly higher in ACLF compared to previous populations studied. Clinical responders generally experienced at

title: Sa1006 Noninvasive Measures of Severity in Chronic Liver Disease. Moving Beyond Fibrosis.

abstract: Background/Aims Chronic liver injury leads to accumulation of fibrous tissue in Disse's space. We postulate that the fractional interstitial volume (FIV) measured using dynamic contrast-enhanced MRI (DCE-MRI) estimates the volume of Disse's space and can be used to predict histological grade of liver fibrosis non-invasively. This pilot study aims to evaluate the accuracy of DCE-MRI to predict severity of liver fibrosis and cirrhosis in patients with chronic liver disease. Methods Chronic liver disease patients undergoing liver biopsy received DCE-MRI and liver stiffness measurement (LSM) via Fibroscan® within 1 month in a prospective. IRB-approved study. AUROC of DCE-MRI was compared against Fibroscan® for diagnosis of significant fibrosis (METAVIR≥ F2). advanced fibrosis (METAVIR≥ F3) and cirrhosis (F4). Results Thirty patients with mean age 48.4±11.4 years and 63.3% males were recruited. Etiology of …

title: Automatic quantification of lobular inflammation and hepatocyte ballooning in NAFLD liver biopsies
author: Scott Vanderbeck and Joseph Bockhorst and David Kleiner and Richard Komorowski and Naga Chalasani and Samer Gawrieh
abstract: Automatic quantification of cardinal histologic features of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) may reduce human variability and allow continuous rather than semiquantitative assessment of injury. We recently developed an automated classifier that can detect and quantify macrosteatosis with greater than or equal to 95% precision and recall (sensitivity). Here. we report our early results on the classifier's performance in detecting lobular inflammation and hepatocellular ballooning. Automatic quantification of lobular inflammation and ballooning was performed on digital images of hematoxylin and eosin–stained slides of liver biopsy samples from 59 individuals with normal liver histology and varying severity of NAFLD. Two expert hepatopathologists scored liver biopsies according the nonalcoholic steatohepatitis clinical research network scoring system and provided annotations of lobular inflammation and hepatocyte ballooning on the digital images. The classifier had precision and recall of 70% and 49% for lobular inflammation. and 91% and 54% for hepatocyte ballooning. In addition. the classifier had an area under the curve of 95% for lobular inflammation and 98% for hepatocyte ballooning. The Spearman rank correlation coefficient for comparison with pathologist grades was 45.2% for lobular inflammation and 46% for hepatocyte ballooning. Our novel observations demonstrate that automatic quantification of cardinal NAFLD histologic lesions is feasible and offer promise for further development of automatic quantification as a potential aid to pathologists evaluating NAFLD biopsies in clinical practice and clinical trials.

title: Paired tumor biopsy analysis and safety data from a pilot study evaluating Tremelimumab-a monoclonal antibody against CTLA-4-in combination with ablative therapy in patients …
author: Austin Duffy and Sid P Kerkar and David E Kleiner and Susanna Ulahannan and Metin Kurtoglu and Oxana Rusher and Suzanne Fioravanti and Melissa Walker and William D Figg and Kathryn Compton and Aradhana Venkatesan and Nadine Abi-Jaoudeh and Brad Wood and Tim F Greten
abstract: BackgroundTremelimumab is a fully human monoclonal antibody that binds to CTLA-4 expressed on the surface of activated T lymphocytes and results in inhibition of B7-CTLA-4-mediated down regulation of T cell activation. Both transcatheter arterial chemoembolization (TACE) and radiofrequency ablation (RFA) have been shown to induce a peripheral immune response which may enhance the effect of anti-CTLA4 treatment in patients with advanced HCC.MethodsPatients with HCC (Childs Pugh A/B7; Barcelona Clinic Liver Cancer Stage C; ECOG 0/1; previously progressed on Sorafenib) are being enrolled in a pilot study of Tremelimumab at 2 dose levels (DL1 and DL2) until disease progression (irRECIST). Subtotal TACE or RFA is performed during study week 6 with DLT evaluation period encompassing first 8 weeks of study. Tumor tissue is collected for analysis at baseline on all patients with optional on-treatment tumor biopsies performed at the time of the radiologic procedure.Results11 pts have been treated so far. 6 pts at DL1 and 5 pts at DL2; M: F 9: 2; Median age= 54 (range 42-75); Cirrhosis present in 7pts. Hepatitis B/C/neg: 3/6/2. 4 pts received TACE. 7 underwent RFA during week 6 of Tremelimumab therapy. Tumor tissue is being collected for analysis at baseline in all patients. Once DL1 was established as safe and feasible on-treatment tumor biopsies are being performed at the time of the radiologic procedure (Day 36+/-96hrs) on all patients. So far 2 of 5 patients treated at DL2 have shown extensive immune cell infiltration on tumor biopsies after 6 weeks of Tremelimumab. More in depth analysis are currently being …

abstract: Immune stimulatory monoclonal antibodies are currently evaluated as anti/cancer agents in clinical trials. While overall toxicity seems to be moderate. liver toxicities have been reported and are not completely understood. Based on the observation that CD11b+Gr-1+ MDSC accumulate in the liver of tumor-bearing mice. we decided to study the effect of anti-CD40 treatment on hepatic MDSC and the liver immune microenvironment. 100 mg agonistic CD40 antibody (FGK-45) or isotype control IgG was injected into naïve and tumor-bearing mice. Liver enzymes. histologies and immune infiltrates were analyzed 24 hours after antibody administration. The effect of CD40 agonist was evaluated using bone marrow chimeras and genetically modified mouse strains CD40-/-and gp91-/-. Mouse and human tumor-induced myeloid suppressive cells were cultured with CD40 agonists to address changes in their immune …

abstract: Purpose: Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) occurs in 10-30% of patients with cirrhosis and carries an in-hospital mortality rate of 30 to 50%. AASLD recommends consideration of primary prophylaxis for SBP amongst patients with low ascitic fluid protein (< 1.5 g/dl) along with impaired renal function (creatinine≥ 1.2 mg/dL. blood urea≥ 25 mg/dL or serum Na≤ 130 mEq/l) or liver failure (Child score≥ 9 and bilirubin≥ 3 mg/dL. Model for end-stage disease (MELD) score is accurate in predicting 3 mo. mortality from cirrhosis and is used worldwide for listing patients for liver transplantation. However. there is no data on its predictive ability on initial SBP occurrence. We performed a retrospective case control study from two tertiary care academic centers to examine association of MELD score and risk of SBP. Methods: Cirrhotic patients with a first episode of SBP (cases) were matched to cirrhotics with ascites but …

abstract: Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is an important cause of liver disease. The prevalence of hepatic steatosis in chronic hepatitis B (CHB) is not well understood. There are reports that low betaine level contributes to hepatic steatosis by increasing oxidative stress. Our aims are to determine the prevalence and impact of hepatic steatosis on CHB and the role of betaine in this disease state. In a single center. HDV or HIV coinfection. other liver diseases and liver transplantation. To date. 231 patients (75% Asians) met the inclusion criteria. Serum betaine levels were measured in 40 randomly selected serum samples from patients with and without steatosis in both genders. abstract: Background: It is known that among patients with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). presence of insulin resistance and diabetes are associated with increased risk of nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) and possibly advanced fibrosis. However. detailed analyses of liver histologic features in patients with NAFLD stratified by their glycemic status have not been systematically done. Aims: To evaluate the histologic findings of normoglycemic. prediabetic. and diabetic patients with biopsy proven NAFLD. Methods: This was a cross-sectional analysis of adult participants enrolled in either the NAFLD Database or the PIVENS trial of the multi-center NIDDK Nonalcoholic Steatohepatitis Clinical Research Network (NASH CRN). Inclusion in analyses required participants to have histology data from a centrally reviewed biopsy within six-months of enrollment. Demographic and histological features of patients with …

abstract: BACKGROUND: Nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) is independently associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD). However. whether this association affects perioperative liver transplant (LT) outcomes is unknown. Thus. we examined the association between NASH and early CVD mortality after LT. METHODS: A cohort of 6.932 adults with NASH or cryptogenic cirrhosis thought secondary to NASH who underwent first LT from 2/2002-12/2012 was identified using the US Organ Procurement and Transplantation Network (OPTN) database. Those listed as status 1 or prior to MELD inception were excluded. Recipient cause of death was manually reviewed and a physician panel adjudicated cases. Logistic regression models examined associations between NASH and early (30-day) CVD mortality. defined as primary cause of death from arterial/pulmonary embolism. arrhythmia. heart failure …

We aimed to assess the impact of these risk factors on the incidence and etiology of cirrhosis as well as the need for liver transplantation in Iceland. abstract: Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is the general term given to liver injury that shares the common feature of macrovesicular steatosis and is unrelated to excessive alcohol consumption. Patients who are biopsied because they are suspected to have NAFLD may show a variety of histological changes which can be organized into specific and non-specific patterns of injury. In studies. the various patterns used include non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH). steatosis without specific features of NASH (sometimes called “NAFLD. not NASH”) and changes. usually minimal. which do meet requirements to diagnose either NAFLD or NASH. Children may show a progressive form of NAFLD which differs from the classic adult type of NASH. These basic categories can be subdivided to provide more information about the disease state and. in addition. the severity of individual disease features can be graded according …

abstract: Objective: Primary human liver cancer (PLC). the third most lethal cancer worldwide. is classified into biologically distinct subgroups. which suggests origin from different hepatic lineage cells. The existence of cancer stem cells (CSCs) was reported in PLC. but the cellular origin of liver CSCs has not been elucidated. Our aim was to investigate the contribution of different hepatic lineage cells to the evolution of CSCs and the phenotypic and genetic heterogeneity of PLC. Methods: Three cell types at different levels of differentiation. including primary mouse hepatic progenitor cells (HPCs). lineage committed hepatoblasts (HBs) and terminally differentiated hepatocytes (AHs) were co-transduced with lentiviral vectors carrying oncogenic H-Ras-Luciferase/EGFP and SV40 large T (LT)-mCherry. CSC properties of FACS sorted H-Ras-EGFP+/SV40LT-mCherry+ cells were tested by standard in vitro and in vivo assays …

title: Hepatitis: 4 case reports
author: DE Kleiner
abstract: Two women and two men. aged 46–76 years. developed hepatitis while receiving ipilimumab for metastatic melanoma. Two patients later died. The patients were enrolled in a clinical trial. in which they were scheduled to receive IV ipilimumab 10 mg/kg every 3 weeks for four doses. One patient received four doses of ipilimumab. while two received three doses. and one patient was administered two doses. The patients developed severe hepatic adverse events 0–20 days after their last ipilimumab dose. with ALT levels peaking at 326–3070 IU/L. Liver biopsy findings were consistent with acute hepatitis in all four patients. with granulomatous hepatitis also noted in one patient. Three patients also developed other inflammatory and non-inflammatory therapy-related adverse events. These included fever. diarrhoea. pruritus. rash. a pigmented macule. adrenal insufficiency. fatigue. hyperhidrosis. hot flashes. sweating …

title: Ocrelizumab/rituximab B-lymphopenia and infections: 4 case reports
author: H Theophile
abstract: A 79-year-old man had discontinued rituximab after four courses due to immunosuppression. Ten months later. he continued to have major B-lymphopenia. and developed septic shock secondary to Listeria monocytogenes meningitis and cytomegalovirus. A 49-year-old woman developed herpes zoster. complicated by meningoradiculitis. more than 2 years after stopping rituximab. At the time of infection. she had lymphopenia. B-alymphocytosis and hypogammaglobulinaemia. A 48-year-old woman developed acute hepatitis E 5 years after ocrelizumab discontinuation. At that time. she had major B-lymphopenia and moderate lymphopenia.

abstract: Purpose: Autosomal Dominant Hyper Immunoglobulin E (IgE) Syndrome (AD-HIES or Job's syndrome) is a primary immunodeficiency with multiple connective tissue. vascular and skeletal abnormalities caused by the signal transducer and activator of transcription gene 3 (STAT3) mutation. These observations support the notion that HCCs can be derived from different cells within the lineage from adult liver stem cell to hepatocyte.AIM: We addressed two questions: (1) does the transforming potential of oncogenes depend on the stage of hepatocytic differentiation and (2) is the tumor phenotype determined by the stage of differentiation at which transformation occurs.METHODS: Fetal (ED16.5) hepatocytes were purified by magnetic sorting and adult (3-month) hepatocytes were isolated by collagenase perfusion from C57BL/6 mice.
